reviewText: Carmageddon TDR 2000 is a fun game,once you become acustomed to its idiosynchrocies.  Most modern computers experience a glitch caused by an antiquated Mip map and vertex fog better handled by Voodoo Rush and TNT Riva cards of yesteryear.  The fix is simple: backup your game cache through Steam first. browse Local Files, Open GFX file with Word Pad. Scroll to line 74 and edit line which reads all twos. Change last two to a zero, Save and done. The game has 25 races and 25 missions. For help with missions check out ZodApe's YewTewb Channel. I have seen complaints on here about the game is broken,too hard,not enough time etc.  Yet i imagine these same complainers plow happily throught the latest NFS broken crap because the Dice Team made it and they made Call of Droopy Diaties. Blow that!  Need more money to buy that sweet Hotty? Try racing the first level in The 20's and for the love of Pete,mow down every ped on the sidewalks. Keep  those Combo Multiplies spinning and you will make serious bank ~ $250K - $600K per play through.  Race it over and over until you have serious ends. Also the Train Station generously has Armor,Power and Slots All Around so you need not buy those,merely fill them for more even more nefarious power. Do You need more time? Use a bigger and slower car to hammer the competition. The Jaws" car is a personal fave. Most Opponent Wasteds yield an extra minute and sometimes more added game play time.  Is this game for everyone? Hell no! You have to work hard to succeed. Without some skin in the game there can be no reward. This is a game from fifteen years  past when games were brutal but satisfying because you felt like you had accomplished something. if it is too hard then maybe Mario Kart or one of it's Brawzillion spinoffs is a better bet for you. reviewText:
About 15 years ago, i was newly curious and exploring computer games as a kid. I made the usual trips to the computer games isle in the Tagret my family frequented. This one time, something caught my eye from an endcap while leaving the games isle. It was the jewel case US version. It looked dark and cool, comparitively to what was on the shelves back then. I asked my mom if she would buy it for me, and she obliged.

The boxart was punk looking and i was into that phase a the time. Crimson red, with chrome lettering. The screenshots on the back were fascinating.

This was my introduction to to the Carmageddon franchise, and community. At the time, it was not so regarded as a turd, at least not so openly by the original devs, but i had no idea of the politics at the time regardless. It was fun. The physics were spot on, collisions were impactful, the vehicles were creative and creatively ripped off from things i'd seen in movies and tv shows of the time, some before my time.

The music, was just what i was into at the time. Odd, punk and metal. I still play the soundrack that i ripped from the disk back then, and thats my preferred way of listening to the music in game now that it isn't included in this version.

The graphics were great, but this was the first title that i realized... i had a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• eMachine. This game was my introduction to learning why my computer was slow and what to do to make it faster, or learn what i would need theoretically to upgrade. It also taught me about modding communities and it blew me away that i could add things to these games. I downloaded everything i could find, 5-10kb/s at a time.... sometimes a car would take all night.

Anyways, despite the devs taking a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• on, and disowning this game, its what lead me down the rabbit hole.

Pros:
Physics are great.
Gameplay is full of carnage.
Music is a good match.
Mods and Add-ons (Max Pack).
Variety of Environments and Cars.
Technology was amazing for the time.
Widescreen support (without 3D stretching; there are 2D textures and hud items that stretch).

Cons:
Glitchy as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• (just hitting an opponent or wall sometimes will crash the game).
Missions can be irritating as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.
Gets easier the more APO you gain.
Weapons could have focused a little more on car to car projectiles.

I'm just glad and grateful, despite hating this game, that the devs allowed it to be on steam at all (it's not on GOG).

reviewText:
This is perhaps one of the best carma games I've playade, but not without it's flaws.

NOTE: I have not played Carmageddon: Reincarnation at the time of writing this, but i have played Carma 1, 2, and have beaten the mobile version.

+ I love how the cars are more responsive than in Stainless's games, although it feels more fitting to drive a car with traction like it's on an ice rink.

- It seems they had problems balancing timer refills; Unlike the other Carma games, you have to pace yourself a bit more. The timer is clamped at 5:00, so there isn't as much time to screw around on a map as the others. It also seems you get a mere couple extra seconds from mowing down 10-15 pedestrians compared to, say, a full minute, or 3, in previous games.

+ The updated graphics are refreshing. They're a bit sharper than Carma2, and the pedestrians don't look as blocky. I'm no texture artist but I think custom car skin support is a nice touch, especially when the textures are exported for you when creating a new skin.

+ Perhaps my favorite track is the racetrack, driving the wrong way and causing a pileup at 200mph is always funny. The splat pack environments are definitely unusual, and add a nice twist to the game.

+ Missions are usually fun.
- Missions get extremely repetitive


tl;dr Carmageddon TDR 2000 is a great game, but time limits and missions feel a bit more serious than a Carma game should.

SHORT VERSION

Expect:Frustrating missions, timer from hell, annoying cops, invisible barriers, PHYSICS!, tiny locales, OP car v car damage, tedious APO system, lots of cars (which you can't afford), accessibility ramps, computers on the roof, mutants, rampant jaywalking, lots of jumping over walls

Do Not Expect:Any feeling of accomplishment, to be able to win by killing all peds, um.. er.. PHYSICS!, a fair fight, an epic boss battle, any variety (despite appearances), a good story, humerous situations to share with friends, friends.

LONG VERSION

It was so tempting to give this game my reccomendation. I played it an awful lot when I was younger, and not knowing a lot else about Carmageddon at the time I really liked this game. Coming back to it after all these years I got to thinking that maybe I should have left the nostalgia as just that, but I craved the sense of fun this used to give me and I just couldn't see where I got it from.

First of all, the game isn't terrible. Running people over and smashing into other cars is still largely taboo in driving games and so is still quite fun to do. It's the execution that lets this title down. The races are the standard Carma Kill all peds, kill all opponents or just finish the allotted number of laps, but it's not that simple. In TDR2000 the timer is most certainly NOT your friend. Want to hunt peds? Forget it. They take forever to kill and only yield a +2 second bonus which hardly offsets the 10+ seconds it took to finish them off in the first place. Want to waste everyone? Fine, but expect them to forget you exist half way through fighting (or in some cases, they don't even want to acknowledge you EVER existed at all.) Just want to race? HAH! Chasing checkpoints will run the clock down by the second lap.

The truth of the matter is, in the races you APPEAR to be given the choice of how to complete them, but they always pan out in exactly the same way because you are constantly chronologically challenged and you pretty much have to waste at least one opponent to stand a chance of completing the event in ANY of the three possible ways.

What else is on offer, you ask?  Well luckily if uniform race completion isn't for you then there are missions". Missions like in GTA? Well... No. Sure you kill some people and race around trashing cars

Well lets start with a little backstory, imagine me about a decade ago, a teenager pining for the glory days of the original Carmageddon, where peds equal points and racing is for wimps, when lo and behold I found it.  A budget re-release copy of Carmageddon TDR2000, and at less than a fiver! I bought it instantly.  Maybe the fact that it's already a re-release title after a couple of years on the shelves should've had alarm bells ringing in my ears, but I bought it nonetheless, and after playing the first batch of races and missions I realised that this isn't the franchise I know and love, and by about halfway through I was bored and fed up with this game. After I completed it, I never touched it again.

So what made this such a terrible gaming experience?  Lets start with the environments. At best they're mediocre, and the locations at least are as varied as the original game, but they also looked more dreary and washed out, and to be honest, rather uninspired. Also, althogh the game engine itself is fairly solid, I've got stuck on the level geometry enough times for it to be annoying.

As for the pedestrians that inhabit the maps, they would be satisfying to run over if they didn't all have adamantine skeletons.  I swear, unless you are going full pelt at them, you have to reverse back over them at least once in order to kill them (and even then it wasn't a guarantee!) If that wasn't bad enough the game only gives you a pittance of a time bonus for running them over. 2 seconds?! It took about that long to kill them in the first place!!!

And the missions, oh god the missions!  Having one or two to break up the game is fine, but there were missions shoe-horned between every ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing race!  I just wanted to cause some carnage.  And if they weren't asinine fetch quests, they were convoluted and tedious, like shooting sharks with a slaughter mortar, which on paper sounds zany and fun, but in a vehicle can be awkward and frustrating to pull off.

Then there are the cars themselves, all the rest might have been forgiven if the cars themselves were fun to drive, but they aren't.  They're ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.  That in itself is a cardinal sin in ANY driving sim, let alone a Carmageddon sequel.

To begin with, the line-up looks like an A-Z from a Poundland toys catalogue, Rangeing from the silly to the uninspired, with things like a motorized wooden hamster wheel, a pallid attempt at a steampunk monster truck, (which looks more like a boiler mounted on a horse cart,) a tank, nothing special, just a tank, and even a man driving a bathtub (really?), none of which fits the game's setting, bar one, Max's own Eagle, which you started with.

Then there are those cars which goes beyond uninspired to just plain lazy: one of the cars is literally called Sports Sedan"
date: and is just that.  I watched a video of this game about a month ago and I couldn't tell the opponent vehicles from the rest of the traffic milling about on the map.  Needless to say you won't be tempted to drive every vehicle in the game.\n\nAs for the handling it's okay for the most part
